bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, February 20, 1942

div1.p: Truby tells Hench that he has received the galley proofs of his book and likes the appearance of the book and illustrations. He mentions having seen Finlay's book and thought it was beautifully done.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, February 20, 1942
div1.opener:
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
Feb. 20, 1942
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
The galley proofs and illustrations
are here and I am hard at work
on them. Will have them on the way
back to Hospers by Tuesday. It has
been quite thrilling to see the thing
in print. The type is excellent and
I am sure it will be a nice
looking job. I figure that the book
will be about 5 × 8 inches in size
with about 250 pages. The illustrations
all came out well. There are 30 of them.
A friend of mine has suggested that
I ask Weyeths to let me use the
Cornwell picture for an illustration as it fits in very
well with my chapter on the credit
for the great achievement. The small print
such as they used on the blotter or the
size larger which they used in the small
booklet “Pioneers of American Medicine” would
be ok as to size. Credit could be given
to Wyeth & Bro which would satisfy them
and I believe it would please Mr Kellogg. I can't
see that there could be any professional
AC
T
from reasons for objecting to reproducing it in a book like
mine. I wanted your opinion, however,
before writing to Mr. Kellogg about it.
I dont think Harpers (Harber) would consent
unless Mr K. would furnish the plates
free as the Contract covers that point.
If you can find time to give me
your slant on this I will be glad.

I hope everything is going well
with Mrs. Hench. Do you expect to be
there in March? I have hoped that
you would drop in here and surprise
me. Remember to take the first chance
you can get & come to S.F. Two sets of
galleys were sent so I will keep one
for you to see.

I have not heard for Gen. Kean
in a long time. Hope he is not ill.

closer.seg:
P.S. I had a glance at Finlay's book
on yellow fever at the Lone Medical
Library. It is beautifully done and
I thought it very fair. Of course I
did not have time to go into details. I
shall read it as soon as I get time.
AEJ
